subject: History
title: Vesalius Remaps the Body
description: A 60-second lesson on Vesalius Remaps the Body.

hook.text: For 1,300 years, doctors trusted Galen's anatomy. Then a young professor actually opened a body and looked.

buildup.text: Andreas Vesalius, just 28, published De Humani Corporis Fabrica in 1543â€”the first accurate anatomy textbook.

discovery.text: He performed dissections himself instead of lecturing from a chair while a barber did the cutting.

twist.text: He found over 200 errors in Galen's work. Galen had dissected animals, not humans, and guessed the rest.

climax.text: Vesalius proved that observation beats authority. Modern anatomyâ€”and evidence-based medicineâ€”began with him.

punchline.text: He trusted his eyes over a 1,300-year-old book.

quiz.question: What did Vesalius discover about Galen's anatomy?
options: It was mostly correct with minor errors
It contained over 200 errors because Galen dissected animals, not humans
It was a complete forgery written by medieval monks
